Let $\omega$ be a complex number such that $\omega^3 = 1.$  Find all possible values of
\[\frac{1}{1 + \omega} + \frac{1}{1 + \omega^2}.\]Enter all the possible values, separated by commas.

ost_step.1: Let $\omega$ represent one cube root of unity. Note that $\omega^3=1$, so $(\omega - 1)(\omega^2 - \omega + 1)=0$. Hence either $\omega = 1$ or $\omega^2-\omega+1=0$. It follows immediately that any value not equal to $1$ satisfies $||\omega||\leq 1$. Thus $|\omega|<1$; i.e., $\left| \frac { 1 }{ 1+\omega }  \right|<\frac{1}{2}$, since $||1+\omega||\geq ||1|| = 1$. As shown below using properties of absolute values, \[\begin{aligned} &\phantom{{}=}}\frac{1}{1+\omega}+\frac{1}{1+\omega^{2}} \\ &= \frac{2+\omega +\omega ^{2}}{(1+\omega)(1+\omega^{2})} \\ &= \frac{2+1}{\left\| \,1+\omega\,\right\|^{2}}\\ &=\frac{3}{\left\|\,1\,\right\|^{2}}=3.\end{aligned}\]Since it doesn't matter what specific roots were used initially because both would yield
ost_step.2: Similarly as above,\[ \begin{aligned} &\phantom{{}=}}\frac{1}{1+\omega}+\frac{1}{1+\omega^{2}} \\ & =\frac{2+\omega +\omega ^{2}}{(1+\omega)(1+\omega^{2})} \\ & = \frac{2+1}{\left\|\,1+\omega\,\right\|^{2}} \\ & = \frac{3}{\left\|\,1\,\right\|^{2}}=3.\end{aligned}\]Thus our original expression always evaluates to $\boxed{3}$.

Multiplying through by $\omega^{-3}$ yields $\omega + \omega^2 + \omega^{-3} = 0$. Rearranging terms results in $\omega^2 + \omega + 1 = -\omega^{-3}$. 1.subquestion: List all three cube roots of unity (the solutions to $\omega^3 = 1$) other than 1 itself.

subanswer.text: The solutions are found using De Moivre's theorem as follows:\begin{align*} & (\cos(\pi/3) + i \sin(\pi/3))^{\,3}\\ &= \cos(\pi)\\ &= -1\\ \\& (\cos(-\pi/3)+i\sin(-\pi/3))^{3}\\ &= -\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i\\ &\qquad=e^{-\pi/3}\\ \\& (\cos(5\pi/3)+i\sin(5\pi/3))^{\,3}\\ &=\cos(5\pi/3)\\ &= -\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i\\ &\qquad=- e^{5\pi/3}\end{align*}So our list includes $\{-\frac{1}{2}, -\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i, e^{- \pi/3},\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i,\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i\}$. The answer is \{-\frac{1}{2}, -\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i, e^{- \pi/3},\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i,\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i\}.

1.subquestion: What does Euler's formula say about powers of $\omega$?

subanswer.text:
Using Euler's formula, we have \[\begin{aligned} &\omega^2+\\&\omega^3 \\= &i\quad i^2=-1\\&-\omega,\end{aligned}\]so $(\omega + i)\omega(\omega - i)=1,$ which implies $|\omega|^2+\omega+i=0.$ This shows that any solution must satisfy $|w|<1.$ In particular, since $|\omega^2+i|\ge |\omega|$ (by triangle inequality), this forces $|\omega|<\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}.$ On the other hand, if $|\omega|>\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$,then taking reciprocals would make them larger than their sum; so our only possibility remains as $|\omega| =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},$$$\Rightarrow w = \frac{-1 + i}{\sqrt{2}}, $$and therefore $$\frac{1}{1 + w}+\frac{1}{1 + w^2}= -\frac{1}{2},$$since both terms equal negative half.

Let $\omega$ be a complex number such that $\omega^3 = 1.$  Find all possible values of
\[\frac{1}{1 + \omega} + \frac{1}{1 + \omega^2}.\]Enter all the possible values, separated by commas.

direct_answer.text:
We know that $|\omega| = 1,$ so
\begin{align*}
\left|\frac{1}{1 + \omega}\right|^2 &= \left|\frac{1 - (\omega^2)}{(\omega - 1)\cdot(\omega^2 + \omega + 1)}\right|^2 \\
&= \frac{|1-\omega^2|^2}{|(\omega - 1)|^2 |(\omega^2 + \omega + 1)|^2} \\
&= \frac{1}{\overline{1+\omega}^2} \\
&= 1.
\end{align*}Hence, $\frac{1}{1 + \omega} + \frac{1}{1 + \omega^2}$ lies on one side of the real axis; without loss of generality, let us assume it lies above. By symmetry about the origin, $|z|$ also determines whether $z$ lies below or above the real axis.

1.subquestion: List all three cube roots of unity (the solutions to $\omega^3 = 1$) other than 1 itself.

subanswer.text: The solutions are found using De Moivre's theorem as follows:\begin{align*} & (\cos(\pi/3) + i \sin(\pi/3))^{\,3}\\ &= \cos(\pi)\\ &= -1\\ \\& (\cos(-\pi/3)+i\sin(-\pi/3))^{3}\\ &= -\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i\\ &\qquad=e^{-\pi/3}\\ \\& (\cos(5\pi/3)+i\sin(5\pi/3))^{\,3}\\ &=\cos(5\pi/3)\\ &= -\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i\\ &\qquad=- e^{5\pi/3}\end{align*}So our list includes $\{-\frac{1}{2}, -\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i, e^{- \pi/3},\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i,\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i\}$. The answer is \{-\frac{1}{2}, -\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i, e^{- \pi/3},\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i,\frac{1}{2}-\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}i\}.

1.subquestion: What does Euler's formula say about powers of $\omega$?

subanswer.text:
Using Euler's formula, we have \[\begin{aligned} &\omega^2+\\&\omega^3 \\= &i\quad i^2=-1\\&-\omega,\end{aligned}\]so $(\omega + i)\omega(\omega - i)=1,$ which implies $|\omega|^2+\omega+i=0.$ This shows that any solution must satisfy $|w|<1.$ In particular, since $|\omega^2+i|\ge |\omega|$ (by triangle inequality), this forces $|\omega|<\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}.$ On the other hand, if $|\omega|>\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}$,then taking reciprocals would make them larger than their sum; so our only possibility remains as $|\omega| =\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},$$$\Rightarrow w = \frac{-1 + i}{\sqrt{2}}, $$and therefore $$\frac{1}{1 + w}+\frac{1}{1 + w^2}= -\frac{1}{2},$$since both terms equal negative half.

direct_answer.text:
We know that $|\omega| = 1,$ so
\begin{align*}

&= \frac{1}{\overline{1+\omega}^2} \\
